text: The system libc is the support software for anything that is written in C that runs on a particular system (which is quite a lot).  Since most software you use depends in some form or another on something written in C, it’s important to compile software for all the different libc configurations that Julia can be used with.

text: To answer your second question, there are small advantages to one over the other.  We support both because different Linux flavors use different libc’s as their system libc library.  So, for instance, Ubuntu uses glibc as its default system libc.  So if you compile your C program against glibc, that binary can run on Ubuntu.  However, if you try to run it on Alpine linux, it will fail, because Alpine uses musl as the default system libc.

text: Most (not all) C code is very easily portable.  The majority of C code that you will write will compile with no modifications on both glibc and musl, so it’s not really a matter of extra effort when writing C code.  It’s just a matter of when building binaries, you have to build multiple different binaries.

attachments.title: The Cathedral and the Bazaar
attachments.text:
The Cathedral and the Bazaar: Musings on Linux and Open Source by an Accidental Revolutionary (abbreviated CatB) is an essay, and later a book, by Eric S. Raymond on software engineering methods, based on his observations of the Linux kernel development process and his experiences managing an open source project, fetchmail. It examines the struggle between top-down and bottom-up design. The essay was first presented by the author at the Linux Kongress on May 27, 1997 in Würzburg (Germany) and was published as part of the book in 1999.
The illustration on the cover of the book is a 1913 painting by Liubov Popova titled Composition with Figures and belongs to the collection of the State Tretyakov Gallery.
The book was released under the Open Publication License v2.0 in 1999.
